Congratulations! What you have proven is that gravity affects the motion of physical objects, even that of clocks. Every clock is based on a physical substance that has a regular, cyclic motion. If the distance the substance moves over a fixed period changes, then the clock speeds up or slows down. This doesn't require a mystical concept of something called "time" that has some universal global "rate" across some global expanse called space. Because physics imagines that there exists some sort of backdrop framework called "space/time" that holds all the physical stuff in place, it comes up with the fallacy that this "space/time" substance has to change in order to accommodate the change in the actual physical materials within it.  You are simply witnessing a change in the motion of a physical object being observed alongside the measurement of change of another physical, cyclic motion.

Just as a completely irrelevant aside:

I worked on GPS in the 90s. We had to correct for tiny discrepancies in calendar time compared to real time (the Earth orbits the Sun every 365.25 days, giving us leap years, but for space we have to count the leap seconds). For orbits, it matters that Earth isn't quite round. It's a bottom-heavy oblate sphere. For the clocks on GPS, it matters that the ground is sometimes closer and sometimes more distant in a perfectly circular orbit, because of elevation changes in the ground itself. Large mountains have their own gravity systems that can change the clock times on something as precise as a cesium beam clock and the speed the bird flies at. I wasn't any kind of a scientist in those days, just the guy who ran the coms for satellite contacts. This all blew my mind.

Contrary to popular opinion, Arthur Eddington's observations of light being bent around a star actually disproved Einstein's Theory of General Relativity.   Einstein himself stated that proving light does not have a constant velocity in vacuum would disprove his theory.  It is not possible for anything with a curved path to have a constant velocity as velocity is both the magnitude and direction of the change in distance with respect to time.  Any time the direction changes, there is an acceleration and the velocity changes.  In order for light to have a constant velocity, it must be traversing a perfect straight line path from its point of origin to its destination.  This does not occur.

What if... a gravitational field slows the mechanical movement of the smallest scale bits of matter in such a way that it acts indistinguishable from a slowing of time. Everything we could possibly use to make the measurement is effected by the density curve of gravity, but time itself is a constant. Or time is an illusion, an emergent property of the fundamental movement of the smallest, constituent parts of our universe.

I think it is foolish to assert that just because general relativity accurately describes a phenomenon it means it has to be the actual explanation for it. We haven't proven general relativity... We've proven a phenomenon occurs. That's the data. How were interpret the data matters because we have based so much on the assumption of that interpretation.

To then further complicate things, we educate others that that assumption is fact, when in fact, we could be wrong.

And when the theory meshes perfectly up to that last .001% of data, we then assume that something must be missing in the data that still makes the theory work instead of leaving room for the entire theory to be wrong. With limited data on every phenomenon possible, multiple theories and the math that expresses them could fit the picture but only one is the right one.

So I say, don't stop asking what if, and leave room for your interpretation of the data to be completely wrong. Because... the universe agrees all all scales, it has to. And quantum and general don't work together so, we need to find one theory that fundamentally works on all scales.

While I hesitate to say this , I think that the interpretation of Einstein's theory of relativity is largely misunderstood . Time is nothing more then a measurement of motion , Not a  dimension and as such is easily manipulated by large gravity wells such as planets , stars , etc. Everything that has mass is effected by gravity including the little parts like protons , neutrons , electrons and even the smaller parts of quantum physics . While exposed to higher gravity these parts experience resistance and thus slow down and when not exposed to large amounts of gravity they speed up . That's why the illusion of time dilation exist when observing this phenomenon at great distance but does not exist when observed at close range . Ie. You are at that time experiencing the same gravitational forces as the object being observed therefore unable to perceive the illusion of time dilation .   For example ; imagine if you will shooting a gun strait up { not recommended btw } while standing on earth . the bullet has resistance therefore it is moving slower then if that same gun were to be shot in space 5000 miles from earth . The same thing happens at the atomic level , the atoms inside your own body . The result of this is the speeding up or slowing down of our human perception which is the only cause of the illusion of time dilation .  In short time is not experiencing dilation of any sort . However our perception of it is distorted . Coincidentally this very simple explanation also explains why time and or our perception of it become distorted at very high speeds as well . This is caused by the maximum speed of the universe , roughly 187 thousand miles per second . The closer you get to that speed the more all the little and very fast parts are forced to slow down . Once again distorting the perception of this measurement we call time .  And last thing I'd like to say is that of course this is just a theory also and will not be able to be proven until we develop technologies that allow us to travel close to the speed of light . NOT THAT WE WOULD EVER WANT TO GO THAT FAST FOR ANY REASON . Because at that speed , no matter the size of your ship , if you hit a space rock the size of a baseball it would completely destroy any ship that you could build . So game over and no at that speed mass does not become infinite but energy does . So that baseball size rock would produce more energy then our sun a billion times over .

Derek, you're not measuring time with a clock. you're just measuring motion - the tick. Just because it moves hands and shows you numbers doesn't mean you're measuring time. Time isn't something you can move through, it's a measure of perceived change.

Time dilation is caused by force dilation "modulated force". It is as simple as, "why does a clock hand arrive earlier and or later than expected to a point on the clock dial?" Answer, clock hands are pushed to their positions by forces, and therefore a modulated position corresponds to modulated push force.

This is an empirically derived deduction, observation, measure. Imagine two identical spring driven clocks, however once having been synchronized now the clock dials have diverged measures of time due to time dilation effect. The clock dials diverged position corresponds to a divergent position of clock springs. Define the clock springs divergent position in terms of Hooke's law which equates to divergent values of force/tension for each spring.

So clocks springs empirically demonstrate force dilation. Question is, does the modulated rate of atomic clocks correspond to force dilation? Atomic clocks rely on an electromagnetic process (a fundamental force) and therefore time dilation effect is definable as a modulated rate of EM force.

Mass is equivalent to sum of atomic forces, and atomic forces are modulated by gravity, dependent upon square law proximity to mass. Factor star population densities, dilate atomic force/mass. The takeaway from this is that increased gravity slows time down and that a person that stays in a higher gravity field than earth can, from their perspective, travel into the future on their return. The amount of time they travel will depend on the difference between the two levels of gravity and the duration spent apart. What this test does is provide a means to accurately measure how much gravity can alter time.

This can prove a problem for future deep space explorations. While a ship is in significantly lower gravity fields compared to earth, their time, when compared, will go by much much faster.

Let me break it down. Say we launch a rocket that has a mission to fly 10 light years (LY) away and then make a u-turn and come back to earth. Hypothetically, if we go half the speed of light, taking 20 years to get there and 20 years to return, 40 years will pass on the ship, but on earth, it would be much more. How much more? We can't know for certain yet.

Additionally, since speed also effects time, the speed you travel those 20 LY can change the time variation even more.

What do you all think of the implications of deep space travel on time? I'd like to read your ideas.

There is 0,832 millisec/year Time difference between two satellites orbiting at 17000 and 26000 km altitude.
This is how you calculate it :
There is a Time dilation of: 1/SQRT(1–GM/((R+17000000)*c^2))) / 1/SQRT(1–GM/((R+26000000)*c^2))) = 1,000.000.000.026379
where G=gravitational constant, M=mass of Earth, R=radius Earth in meters, and c=light speed
So a clock on 26000 km altitude would gain Time on a clock at 17000 km altitude by :
( 1,000.000.000.026379 – 1 ) * 60 * 60 * 24 * 365,25 = 0,000832 sec/year ( that is 0,832 millisec/year )
See my YouTube video for more examples of speed and gravitational time dilation : https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=hYMvJum9_Do

One flaw: there is no "gravitational part" that is distinguishable from the "velocity part". The math works not because the gravitational part can be separated out, it works because the gravitational part (i.e., the whole of general relativity) accounts for all of the effects due to gravity and velocity both.

If you try to do the math separately and combine the results, you'll get the wrong answer, because you double-count the velocity effect. A good example is how to calculate the speed of a clock at the north pole at sea level (closer to earth's center, and no translational velocity) vs the speed of a clock at the equator at sea level (further from the center of the earth, and moving faster). If you do the math separately, you get the result that clock speeds are different. They aren't different. The general relativistic solution is that they are on an equipotential surface (sea level at both locations!) and therefore tick at the exact same rate.
